author: @NewsChannel10
title: State Fire Marshal's Office report shows Panhandle-Plains Historical Museum violations
text:
Report shows Panhandle-Plains Historical Museum fire and safety violations
AMARILLO, Texas (KFDA) - Since the announcement of the Panhandle-Plains Historical Museum closing on March 24, we have obtained the report that led to that closure.
The 52 page report outlines the violations that the State Fire Marshal’s Office found during the January inspection.
Some of the issues range from minor infractions to others that could be considered more severe.
Exposed wiring was located in numerous areas throughout the building. Some light fixtures were found hanging by the wires.
The ceiling in the IT room was found to be damaged with more exposed wiring.
Investigators found an electrical panel with circuit breakers tied together using copper wire.
They also report excessive amounts of combustibles stored throughout the structure.
Some safety concerns were also noted, stating the excessive length it would take visitors to reach an exit during an emergency.

author: Abbas Adil
title: (IMD) predicts above-normal rainfall in August and September, indicating a high likelihood of landslides and floods. – Shafaqna India | Indian Shia News Agency
text: Shafaqna India: India is forecasted to receive above-normal rainfall in August and September, with the possibility of La Nina conditions developing by late August, according to the India Meteorological Department (IMD). This heightened rainfall increases the risk of landslides and floods. The monsoon is essential for 52% of India’s cultivated land and for replenishing water reservoirs. The IMD predicts rainfall in August and September to be 106% of the long-period average of 422.8 mm. India has already recorded 453.8 mm of rain, a 2% surplus, since June 1 due to a wetter-than-normal July after a dry June. IMD chief Mrutyunjay Mohapatra noted that normal to above-normal rainfall is expected across most of the country, except for parts of the northeast, east India, Ladakh, Saurashtra, Kutch, and areas of central and peninsular India, which might see below-normal rainfall. He also mentioned that the western Himalayan region might experience deficient rainfall. La Nina conditions, which bring cooler-than-normal waters in the central Pacific Ocean aiding monsoon rains in the Indian subcontinent, may set in by the end of August. Above-normal temperatures are expected across much of the country, with normal to below-normal temperatures likely in the Gangetic plains, central India, and the southeast coast. In July, India saw 9% more rainfall than usual, with the central region receiving 33% excess rain. This consistent rainfall for three consecutive monsoon seasons has benefited central India’s agriculture. However, east and northeast India experienced a 23% rainfall deficit, and northwest India saw a 14% deficit, though improvement is expected in August and September. Significant deficits were noted in east Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Jharkhand, Gangetic West Bengal, and parts of the northeast, with expected recovery. Rainfall deficits in Haryana, Punjab, Himachal Pradesh, and Jammu and Kashmir ranged from 35% to 45%. Central and southern India received surplus rain due to the monsoon trough’s southward position. The Indian monsoon’s variability is influenced by natural factors, but climate change is increasing this variability, leading to more extreme weather and dry spells.

author: Europa Press
title: Fútbol.- El Real Madrid se lleva el derbi ante el Madrid CFF y responde a las goleadas de Levante y Atlético
text:
(Atención abonados, corrige anterior teletipo en titular y quinto párrafo por error en la segunda plaza que es del Levante por goles y distancia de puntos del Madrid CFF)
MADRID, 7 Ene. (EUROPA PRESS) -
El FC Barcelona arrancó el año 2024 en la Liga F 2023-2024 con una goleada ante el Levante Las Planas para afianzar su liderato en una decimotercera jornada marcada por la remontada épica del Real Madrid ante el Madrid CFF y las goleadas a domicilio del Levante UD y Atlético de Madrid, este último con protagonismo para Sheila Guijarro, autora de un póquer goleador.
El conjunto blaugrana retornó a la acción mostrando su poderío ofensivo en el Johan Cruyff en el derbi ante el Levante Las Planas, que no pudo aguantar demasiado al actual campeón de Europa que ya mandaba en el marcador a los cinco minutos por medio de Salma Paralluelo. Mariona Caldentey, de penalti, Aitana Bonmatí y Caroline Graham Hansen dejaron el choque ya sentenciado antes del descanso y tras este se unieron a las 'fiesta' goleadora Claudia Pina, Asisat Oshoala y un doblete de Patri Guijarro, mientras que Allegra Poljak hizo el tanto del honor del conjunto visitante.
Por detrás del equipo de Jonatan Giráldez y en plena pugna por la segunda y la tercera plaza siguen el Real Madrid, el Levante UD y el Atlético de Madrid, con el Madrid CFF descolgándose este fin de semana tras dejar escapar la victoria en el Alfredo di Stéfano cuando la tenía en su mano.
El derbi madrileño fue muy igualado y constató que el conjunto de Alberto Toril no está excesivamente fino. Sufrió algo más la primera parte, pero en la segunda se topó con una excelsa Ulloa que paró todas las acometidas madridistas. Cuando parecía que el partido acabaría sin goles, Cristina Librán, en el 91, dio ventaja a las visitantes, que se quedaron finalmente con la miel en los labios por el arreón final de las locales, que con goles de Ivana Andrés en el 95 y de Caroline Moeller en el 99 defendieron la segunda plaza liguera.
El Madrid CFF cae a la quinta plaza a tres puntos de un Real Madrid que, pese al triunfo, perdió por la diferencia de goles la segunda plaza con un Levante UD, con el que está empatado a puntos. El equipo 'granota' no falló en su derbi regional ante el Villarreal, al que derrotó claramente por 0-5 con un triplete de la colombiana Mayra Ramírez y un doblete de Alba Redondo para superar a las madridistas.
A un punto de ambos se encuentra el Atlético de Madrid, que también firmó una clara goleada por 1-6 en su visita al Valencia, aunque fueron las valencianistas las que se adelantaron en el marcador por medio de Paula Sancho. Sin embargo, ahí apareció una letal Sheila Guijarro, que se colocó como nueva 'pichichi' con once goles gracias a un póquer de dianas en poco más de 20 minutos, del 14 al 36. Eva Navarro y Gaby García cerraron el marcador en la segunda mitad.
Intentando engancharse a este 'tren Champions' continúa el Sevilla, que agravó aún más la situación del colista Sporting Club Huelva, al que batió a domicilio (1-3), y que es sexto clasificado con un punto de ventaja sobre el Athletic Club que se llevó su derbi (2-0) ante la SD Eibar y adelantó en la tabla a una Real Sociedad que dejó escapar una ventaja de 3-1 ante el Costa Adeje Tenerife, que arañó n punto finalmente con un tanto de María José Pérez en el 95.
Finalmente, el 2024 trajo una alegría para el Granada, penúltimo clasificado que no ganaba desde la primera jornada y que cogió aire en su intento de salvación al ganar 2-3 a domicilio al Betis con un gol en el minuto 93 de Carlota Suárez que supuso la cuarta derrota consecutiva de las béticas.

author: Carmen Klassen
title: Not Alone
text: A phone call from a fellow military chaplain was the catalyst for Maj. Ryan Carter. In June 2020, Carter remembers the conversation where his colleague wanted action in the wake of George Floyd’s death. “She said … it’s time we have a conversation about it,” recalled Carter, who says he was also struggling to process Floyd’s death and the ensuing calls to end racial injustice. “It was a very difficult moment for many racialized members within the CAF, particularly Black members, myself included.” It was the push Carter says he needed. Teaming up with a more experienced chaplain, he sought the support of their chain of command to set up a new forum. His vision was simple: to create a space where Black, Indigenous and other racialized members could have honest conversations about racial discrimination in their workplace. In the past three years it has grown to include as many as 80 Canadian Forces members and Department of National Defence (DND) employees from across the country and from all ranks, for about six virtual discussions a year. For Carter, though it was no surprise to hear members’ accounts of racism, it’s a powerful thing to share those lived experiences first-hand — and for colleagues of all backgrounds, including non-racialized members, to hear it. “That’s where change happens in my mind. Attaching the moment to the emotions and experiences of the person.” Pizza as systemic racism Carter’s own encounters with racism go as far back as his first military assignment as a Muslim chaplain in Alberta. “I would come to work every so often and find a slice of pepperoni pizza in front of my office,” he recalls. At first, he thought it might be a mistake. But then, he noticed something while on an operation with the unit. “I found … a slice of pepperoni pizza on my pillow. So at that moment, I realized what was happening, that I was the victim of anti-Muslim hate.” Carter says he often hears stories like his in the Talking About Race forum — painful accounts of members feeling targeted or excluded, experiencing verbal assaults and being passed over again and again for new opportunities. “When someone first describes their experience of being marginalized … a comment about their hairstyle or the beard or … the colour of their skin, or a passing remark about their religion. It hurts.” Last year, [a damning report by a panel of retired Canadian Armed Forces members](https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/military-report-racism-1.6429794) called out widespread discrimination in the military, detailing “marginalization, microaggressions and overt racism on a regular basis.” The panel specifically noted Black members have been targeted and unfairly passed over for career opportunities — with progression “seriously hampered by systemic discrimination.” Slow progress In his 42 years with the forces, Master Warrant Officer Aldwin Albino says he’s been the target of overt racism on many occasions, including being called the N-word and being introduced in a performance as a “dancing monkey.” But he most acutely feels the injustice of being passed over. He’s now a band sergeant major with the Royal Canadian Artillery Band, which he believes is a first for a Black member of the Canadian Armed Forces. It took nearly a dozen years and a hard fight to win the advancement, he says, all while watching a stream of colleagues who joined after him rise to positions above him. At first, Albino resisted the idea that the colour of his skin was the barrier to his promotion but friends, family and co-workers urged him to consider the possibility. “They said, ‘Do you know that you’re being held back?’ And it became very difficult for me to grasp that something like that would be happening not only in today’s society, but in an institution that I absolutely adore and love,” said Albino. He says he did everything in his power to increase his Forces score — used to determine promotions — from paying for French lessons out of pocket to accepting positions where he felt advancement seemed certain. But in his case, it didn’t happen. “I left [that particular position] the only one never promoted, never commissioned.” Albino eventually filed a grievance, questioning why colleagues with less experience had been promoted instead of him. Several months later he was granted the promotion, but he says he was frustrated to learn it meant yet another move, his 14th. With just two years before retirement, he took on the new role and his grievance was considered closed. Not just in my head Albino now shares what he went through as a regular panelist in the Talking About Race sessions, where he says many participants echo his experiences. It’s helped him counter the pervasive narrative that the way he was treated was “all in his head.” “That’s what happens to a lot of us. ‘Is this really happening? Am I really seeing this clearly?’” he said. “No, it is happening. No, you’re not alone. And … we’re here to help you.” Speaking freely In the wake of last year’s advisory panel, the DND team leadership acknowledged its findings of systemic racism. In early 2023, the CAF’s [Chief Professional Conduct and Culture](https://www.canada.ca/en/department-national-defence/corporate/organizational-structure/chief-professional-conduct-culture.html) and its former anti-racism secretariat established an anti-racism working group, tasked with addressing the issues raised in the report, and with creating an action plan to be fully implemented by 2025. Cmdr. Éloi Gunn, also a chaplain, knows there are other initiatives within the Canadian Forces to support racialized members and improve the channels for identifying and reporting systemic racism. But Gunn says he helped create this forum with Carter because there was nowhere for individual members’ first-person stories to be heard, without judgment or consequence. “You can see people expressing many concerns that they don’t feel like expressing to the chain of command, whether because they are afraid that they’ll [see] reprisals,… but on that platform, people are free to speak.” For him, it’s also an opportunity for members in higher ranks to hear stories they otherwise might not. Though he feels there’s a long way to go to address systemic discrimination in the Forces, and he acknowledges a virtual conversation alone won’t solve it, Gunn says nothing changes if members aren’t allowed to raise their voices. “If people are not talking, they are in silence. Bad things happen.” Future forum Carter also acknowledges the forum’s limitations. But, for him, these kinds of grassroots discussions still matter. “If [people] don’t know that they have a voice, they won’t use the system the way it’s supposed to be used. They won’t take action.” He says he believes strengthening those voices can have a real impact. “It’s about the capacity of people on the ground to generate change.”

author: Lauren Watson
title: Family sues McDonald’s, Taylor Farms after allegedly contracting E. coli from eating Quarter Pounders
text:
Family sues McDonald’s, Taylor Farms after allegedly contracting E. coli from eating Quarter Pounders McDonald’s and Taylor Farms were named in an E. coli lawsuit filed by a woman claiming she and her daughter got an illness at a Colorado Springs location. (Source: KKTV) By Lauren Watson , Lindsey Grewe and Gray News staff Published: Dec. 19, 2024 at 7:18 PM CST | Updated: 2 hours ago Email This Link
Share on Facebook
Share on X (formerly Twitter)
Share on Pinterest
Share on LinkedIn
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. ( KKTV /Gray News) - A woman is suing McDonald’s and Taylor Farms after she and her daughter allegedly became ill after eating food at the restaurant.
According to the lawsuit, the mother and her daughter ordered Quarter Pounders at the McDonald’s on South 8th Street in Colorado Springs on Oct. 17.
The suit alleges that the next day, both were experiencing symptoms of E. coli, went to the hospital, and were diagnosed with viral gastroenteritis.
Attorneys say Tuesday’s lawsuit is the first with a minor child plaintiff related to the recent outbreak earlier this fall .
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has confirmed more than 100 cases in the McDonald’s E. coli outbreak in September and October, including 34 that required hospitalization and one death. Fourteen states reported cases, with Colorado being the hardest hit with more than 30 cases.
McDonald’s has said the outbreak stemmed from the slivered onions in its Quarter Pounders, and it temporarily pulled the item from the menu. The company has linked the contaminated onions to Taylor Farm’s Colorado Springs-based facility.
KKTV has reached out to both McDonald’s and Taylor Farms for a response to the lawsuit.
McDonald’s said they are not commenting on active litigation, but provided a portion of a message from the company’s US president, Joe Erlinger, addressing impacted customers:
“I also want to address customers who ate at McDonald’s and are feeling any number of things: ill, scared, or uncertain. I know that our relationship is built on trust. You trust us to serve you safe food every time. On behalf of the McDonald’s system, I want you to hear from me: we are sorry. For those customers affected, you have my commitment that, led by our values: we will make this right.”
